Delo mešanih patrulj bodo še okrepili
04 Nov 2019, 17:27 by Sijan Pretnar

Na generalni policijski upravi so potrdili, da bodo mešane, slovensko-italijanske patrulje nadaljevale z delom. Njihovo delo se bo še okrepilo, so dodali. Čeprav se je konec septembra formalno končalo trimesečno poskusno delovanje mešanih patrulj, so slovenski in italijanski policisti tudi minuli mesec skupno nadzirali obmejno območje.



Slovenska in italijanska policija bosta še okrepili sodelovanje na meji med državama za zajezitev nezakonitih prehodov meje. Foto: Leo Caharija

LJUBLJANA > Pred dnevi sta se v Trstu srečali vodstvi mejnih policij obeh držav in se na podlagi dosedanji izkušenj z mešanimi patruljami dogovorili, da bodo še okrepili sodelovanje v boju proti nezakonitemu priseljevanju in tihotapcem ljudi, ki delujejo na tako imenovani balkanski poti, pojasnjujejo na generali policijski upravi. Prisotnost policistov na terenu bodo še okrepili. Mešane patrulje bodo z delom nadaljevale tako na območju koprske kot novogoriške policijske uprave.
“Obe strani ocenjujeta, da gre za učinkovito obliko operativnega sodelovanja,” je poudarila Vesna Drole, vodja sektorja za odnose z javnostmi na generalni policijski upravi. Z italijanske strani meje sicer prihajajo pomisleki o učinkovitosti mešanih patrulj. Na slovenski strani pa zdaj napovedujejo, da se bo število patrulj podvojilo. Na sestanku v Trstu so se dogovorili, da bo na obmejnem območju na terenu osem patrulj na teden (prej so bile štiri), ena bo na območju novogoriške policijske uprave, ostale na območju koprske. Predstavniki mejnih policij so se dogovorili še, da si bodo bolj sprotno izmenjevali informacije, kar bo prispevalo k fleksibilnemu načrtovanju mešanega patruljiranja na območjih, ker so nedovoljeni prehodi bolj pogosti.
Poskusno obdobje skupnega nadziranja meje so sicer na policiji ocenili kot uspešno že v začetku oktobra. V tem obdobju so na območju PU Koper zaradi nezakonitega prestopa zunanje meje obravnavali 1922 tujcev. Lani so jih v istem obdobju obravnavali 1785. Na območju PI Nova Gorica so v tem obdobju obravnavali 42 oseb, v enakem obdobju lani pa 33.
Vesna Drole je še pojasnila, da bodo mešane patrulje delovale izmenično na ozemljih obeh držav, tako kot doslej, in sicer na podlagi natančne analize poti, ki jih uporabljajo migranti. Ob tem bodo upoštevali obveščevalne informacije, ki si jih izmenjujejo policijske enote obeh držav. “Tako da bodo postale bolj učinkovito orodje za odvračanje od nezakonitega priseljevanja,” je poudarila Droletova.
Mešane patrulje bodo z delom nadaljevale v okviru sporazuma med italijansko in slovensko vlado o čezmejnem policijskem sodelovanju, podpisanem v letu 2007, je še dodala. Med julijem in septembrom so mešane patrulje sicer delovale na podlagi posebnega izvedbenega dogovora med obema policijama.

The work of mixed patrols will be further enhanced
04 Nov 2019, 16:27 by Sijan Pretnar

The General Police Directorate confirmed that mixed, Slovenian-Italian patrols will continue their work. Their work will be further enhanced, they added. Although the three-month mixed patrols trial formally ended at the end of September, Slovenian and Italian police also jointly controlled the border area last month.



Slovenian and Italian police will further strengthen border co-operation between the two countries to curb illegal border crossings. Photo by Leo Cahari

LJUBLJANA> Leaders of the border police of the two countries met in Trieste a few days ago and agreed on the basis of their past experience with mixed patrols to intensify their cooperation in combating illegal immigration and smugglers of people active on the so-called Balkan route. to the police department. The presence of police officers on the ground will be further enhanced. Mixed patrols will continue their work in the area of the Koper and Novo mesto police headquarters.
"Both sides consider this to be an effective form of operational cooperation," said Vesna Drole, Head of Public Relations at the General Police Directorate. The Italian side of the border, however, has concerns about the effectiveness of mixed patrols. On the Slovenian side, however, they predict that the number of patrols will double. At a meeting in Trieste, it was agreed that there would be eight patrols per week in the border area (four were previously), one would be in the area of the Nova Gorica Police Administration, the rest would be in the area of Koper. Border police officials also agreed to exchange information more regularly, which will contribute to the flexible planning of mixed patrols in the areas, as illicit crossings are more common.
The pilot period of joint border control was assessed as successful by the police in early October. During this period, 1922 foreigners were treated in the territory of the Koper Police Directorate for illegal crossing of the external border. Last year, they were treated in the same period as 1785. In the PI Nova Gorica area, 42 persons were treated during this period, and 33 in the same period last year.
Vesna Drole further explained that the mixed patrols will operate alternately in the territories of the two countries, as they did before, based on a thorough analysis of the routes used by migrants. In doing so, they will take into account the intelligence exchanged between police units of both countries. "So that they will become a more effective tool to deter illegal immigration," Drolet said.
The mixed patrols will continue their work under the agreement between the Italian and Slovenian governments on cross-border police cooperation signed in 2007, she added. Otherwise, between July and September, mixed patrols operated under a specific implementation arrangement between the two police forces.
